prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACSJ2155.6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain high-resolution (beam=0.2") Band-6 (230 GHz) continuum images of bright cluster-lensed SMG discovered by the Herschel Lensing Survey.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will use the correlator in the standard Band 6 continuum mode. That is, with four basebands, each with a 1875 MHz bandwidth and 31.250 MHz resolution.

We would like to request 0.2" resolution for our imaging for the following reasons:
(1) If a source is multiply lensed, it could break up into fairly compact (~1") multiple components (see Figure 1 and 2, for example). Therefore, we would like to be able to spatially resolve each of these ~1" multiply lensed images.
(2) Even when a source is intrinsically large (e.g., gravitational arcs), we would like to be able to probe their internal structures (e.g., individual star-forming regions), which would also require a high resolution.
(3) The 0.2" resolution is similar to those of HST WFC3/IR near-IR images, so it will enable us to compare ALMA and HST WFC3/IR images with a comparable resolution.
We are mainly interested in detecting fine structures of lensed images, so we request the largest angular scale to be 2".

To obtain 0.2" resolution images of our bright lensed SMGs, a natural choice would be either Band 6 or Band 7. Here, we have chosen Band 6 for the following reasons:
(1) To observe multiply lensed images simultaneously, we would often need a FOV of D~30" (see Figures 1 and 2). The size of the Band 6 primary beam is ~30", satisfying this requirement.
(2) Band 6 is more forgiving than Band 7 in terms of the required sky condition, which will increase the chance of scheduling our observations.
(3) Our target galaxies are bright enough that we can easily achieve the required sensitivity in Band 6 even though the source brightness drops from Band 7 to Band 6.
All our target sources have a peak flux density of ~100 mJy in one of the three SPIRE bands (250, 350, and 500 um). To calculated the required sensitivity, we assume a case where a galaxy has a peak flux density of ~100 mJy at ~250um (i.e., z~1 galaxies). These galaxies would be the faintest in our sample because of the largest band spacing (250 um - 1.3mm), that would result in the largest drop in continuum brightness. Based on the fitting of various model galaxy SEDs, we would expect a 1.3mm flux density of ~5 mJy for such a galaxy.
We will achieve a 1.3mm continuum sensitivity of 0.1 mJy to detect such a 5 mJy source with a signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio of 50. Even if the source breaks up into a few/several multiple images, we will be able to achieve an S/N of >10 for each image. Note that many of the target sources are likely brighter than 5 mJy at 1.3mm, which would further increase the resulting S/N. With ALMA in Cycle 3, it only takes a few minutes on source to achive this sensitiviy. Therefore, it is not practical to aim at a poorer sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: To discover exceptionally bright cluster-lensed submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) like the Cosmic Eyelash, our team has been conducting a large Herschel survey of gravitationally lensed galaxies in the fields of massive galaxy clusters: The Herschel Lensing Survey (HLS) (PI: Egami). The HLS has obtained deep PACS (100/160 um) and SPIRE (250/350/500 um) images of 54 massive galaxy clusters as well as shallower (but nearly confusion-limited) SPIRE images of 527 clusters with a total observing time of ~420 hours. Now completed, the HLS has identified a number of exceptionally bright Herschel sources that are likely cluster-lensed SMGs at z>1. Here, we propose to obtain high-resolution (beam=0.2'') ALMA dust continuum images (at 1.3mm) of these bright cluster-lensed SMGs discovered by the HLS. ALMA high-resolution images are essential for, (1) identifying the lensing geometry, (2) examining the relation between the submillimeter source and the counterparts detected at shorter wavelengths, and (3) probing the physical properties of individual star-forming regions through the reconstruction of the source-plane image.
